intro: Sisyrinchium azureum, commonly known as blue-eyed grass, is a member of the Iridaceae family and is native to the western United States. It is a low-growing perennial herb with slender, grass-like leaves and delicate, blue to violet flowers. The plant typically blooms in early spring, producing small, showy flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in meadows and open woodlands. The genus Sisyrinchium is characterized by its striking blue flowers and its role in early season pollination ecosystems.
